subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I'd
like to talk about avatars. If
you’ve seen the movie, Avatar, you may or
may not know that when I first heard the
term - it was a Sanskrit term - and it
referred to individuals who were the
incarnation of God, incarnation of the
absolute ultimate deity. In Hindu
tradition, typically, avatars are
associated with the god Vishnu. Krishna,
for example, was an incarnation of Vishnu.
I understand today in India there
are any number of people whose
followers believe they are avatars,
which typically would mean incarnations
of Vishnu, or incarnations of Krishna. One
doesn’t so much hear about incarnations
of other deities, but why not? Now, of
course, the great movie Avatar suggests a
broader definition. That is, anytime one
person’s consciousness is occupying or
taking over or possessing the body of
any other individual, that possessed
individual becomes an avatar for the
consciousness of the first person. So, in
video games it's quite common now. You
have a character on the screen, it could
be anything whatsoever, it's your
avatar,
you are the consciousness behind that
character.In my lifetime, I was
first exposed to the idea of the avatar
as an undergraduate in college at the
University of Wisconsin. As I recall, it
was my junior year, maybe my senior year
when I took a course on the religions of
India. At that time, I wrote a term
paper on a fellow named Meher Baba, who
was
viewed by his followers as an avatar.
Meher Baba was really, I think, a fellow
who merited some praise. He was a guru,
his teachings were pretty much standard
Hindu teachings. When my professor
graded my term paper back then, he
pointed out how practically everything
that Meher Baba was saying was quite
consistent with mainstream thought in
Indian religion.But, there were some
intriguing things about him. One was that
he took a vow of silence.
So, during his active years as the avatar,
he never spoke. He only meditated. He was
with people. Maybe he had a slate, or sign
language, he must have had a way to
communicate with people. Another
interesting thing he did, is that he
would sit and meditate with certain
people. He called them the mad musts, or
the God intoxicated individuals. These
were people who were so devoted to God
they were completely intoxicated
with devotion and therefore end up in
mental institutions. They seemed
completely psychotic. But he had a way of
sitting in meditation with them and
getting through to them and helping them
in some way along their path. So, I had
very positive feelings about Meher Baba
in those days. Although, I never met him. I
was never in the presence of Meher Baba.
Studying his works and his life made
me feel somewhat positive, it
didn't seem like he was doing any harm.
Now another avatar I actually did meet:
Franklin Jones also known as Adi Da Samraj
and is regarded by his followers to
this day as an avatar. He founded a
religion, the Johannine Daist Communion.
Throughout his life he has had many
names. I think his first book, The Knee of
Listening, was published under his birth
name of Franklin Jones. After that it
was Da Love Ananda, Adi Da, Adi
Da Samraj, and any number of names.
When he first came on the scene he
was known for what he called crazy
wisdom. Now, crazy wisdom is a trait
associated with a certain class of gurus.
Chögyam Trungpa, the Tibetan lama, would
be one such. George Gurdjieff might be
another. Timothy Leary, Aleister Crowley.
Typically the crazy wisdom gurus are the
tantric gurus who are having sex with
their followers. Adi Da Samraj was
one such individual. You can imagine,
he formed a spiritual community around
himself and written several books and
many, many acclaimed people in the field
of consciousness and spirituality are
praising his books: Alan Watts, Larry
Dossey, Ken Wilbur, have all written high
praise for this man. In fact, they have a
quote from me as well. Here is what I
said, I said I think that the community
around him has formed a very
penetrating social and spiritual
experiment and I think there's something
for that. If you wanted to have a really
intense experience with a spiritual
master, he’s your man.
He noticed, I think early on, when
all of these people were adulating
him, you know, the incarnation of God,
he noticed that many of his disciples, if
he asked them honestly, they’d say, “I’d
love to have sex with you.” You know,
have sex with God? Whoa! So, he obliged them.
They went through a phase, they call
it the garbage and the goddess
phase in which they engaged in all sorts
of activity with drugs and alcohol and
sex. He lived with, I think at one
time, maybe as many as nine wives.
In addition to that, slept with the wives
of many of his other devotees. I’m not
aware that he had sex with any males, but
I wouldn’t be surprised if that were
also the case.Then at some point in
time, I think after a few lawsuits, they
ended that phase and he went back to
maybe a more traditional, spiritual
community. Now, I did have the opportunity
to visit their sanctuary in northern
California on one occasion when the
master was there. I sat in his
presence. I wanted to interview him.
In fact, they sent representatives
specifically for the purpose of
soliciting me to join their organization,
to endorse what they were doing.
Really, all I wanted was an interview. I’m
not a joiner, really. It's enough to be a
secular Jew. But they told me, he only
speaks to devotees. He’s never given a
press interview. Never even speaks to
people outside the community. So, when I
was there, it was a ritual of some sort,
he was in a trance state, it seemed,
of some sort. Then we left.
The people around him, you would have
thought he was Elvis Presley, the way if
he appeared around a group of his
devotees, they’d start screaming like
teenage girls, screaming after Elvis or
the Beatles. I thought it was
fascinating, the power that he had over
these people. To me, that's the really
interesting thing. Based on all
of the high praise his various books
have received, you’d think the man was
something of a spiritual genius. But when
you look at the lawsuits, when you look
at
his life, when you look at the apparent
nervous breakdowns he went through when
it became clear that the whole world
wasn't going to worship him as the great
spiritual master of the age, you get a
feeling that in spite of his enormous
spiritual psychic attainments, and there
are many individuals I’ve spoken to who
would testify to that, he was nevertheless
something of a flawed individual, which
doesn't surprise me. I guess while I
consider myself a secular Jew, there’s
one thing from the Jewish tradition, well
many things, but one thing right now on
my mind that stuck with me. That is
the idea that humans are not God. That
humans can never be God. That humans, well,
in the Jewish tradition, the
greatest of all prophets, it is said, was
Moses. Well, I think the Jewish religion
took a wrong turn with Moses, but in
spite of that, Moses is considered the
greatest of all prophets. It was said
he was such a great prophet that before
Moses died, he was given the vision of
the face of God.
He saw God’s punning [sp?], his face. Then
he died. You see, because that's about as
close as any human can get to God. You
can see the face of God but you won't be
able to handle it. It will blow out your
nervous system, essentially. And that's it.
You're out of here.Ted Owens, the PK
Man who I studied and who considered
himself the greatest of all psychics
since Moses, he said, “They searched for
centuries and centuries to find someone
with a nervous system strong enough to
handle it.” Well, he was, I would say, a very
flawed individual. So, I’m accustomed to
the idea that people can
have great qualities, enormous spiritual
attainments, and still be flawed human
beings. Maybe not as advanced as some
little munchkins
who have no particular talents but are
good people.Now, let me say this about
Da Love-Ananda, and that is, because I
lived in San Rafael where he had a
bookstore and where the church
headquarters were located at one time, I
did get to know a number of people who
were part of that community. Some of them
came to me in the days when I was a
psychotherapist and were clients of
mine. Others came to try to recruit
me, so I’ve had some contact with them.
I can say this, some of my closest
colleagues and friends, became devotees.
Lee Sannella, the ophthalmologist who wrote
a very important book, Kundalini
Experience: Psychosis or Transcendence, became a
devotee and lived in that spiritual
community.Russell Targ’s wonderful
daughter, Elizabeth Targ, about whom
Russell and I have created a separate
video conversation - I’m linking to it
right now - but Elizabeth, at the time of
her death, was a devotee.
These are people I highly respect, very
evolved individuals. They would tell
me things like this. They would say, he
meditates you. You don't have to meditate,
you just go into your posture for
meditation and then he will come and
meditate you. So, I have no doubt that
many of the people who interacted with
him on many, many levels got something
back of value. I was earlier reading a
critique of him and they said it would be a
great mistake to consider him just
another phony guru,
even though he caused great harm and
damage to some individuals who couldn't
maybe handle the intensity of this
penetrating social experiment.What
does this mean for you? Are there people
in your life who are, at the one hand
very uplifting, people who awaken you to
higher realities, and at the same time
are also somewhat destructive? How do you
deal with that, in your life? Have you
ever encountered that, or are you likely
to ever encounter that? How would you
encounter that? Can you avoid the
charisma or the temptation of someone
who has that kind of charisma and power?
I’ll just close by asking one other
question. Do you ever wonder what might
happen if such an individual were to get
into politics? An individual with that
kind of personal power and charisma, whose
followers would worship them as
God on Earth? Is that a good thing? Is
that a bad thing? Do we even have any
say? Those are all thoughts to
consider. I’ll leave you with those
thoughts. Once again, thank you for
being with me.
[credits]
